path: Step 1: Represent the statements as set inclusions. 'All Bloops are Razzies' means the set of Bloops is a subset of the set of Razzies. We can write this as B ⊆ R.
Step 2: Similarly, 'All Razzies are Lazzies' means the set of Razzies is a subset of the set of Lazzies. We can write this as R ⊆ L.
Step 3: Apply the transitive property of set inclusion. If B ⊆ R and R ⊆ L, then B ⊆ L. This means the set of Bloops is a subset of the set of Lazzies.
Step 4: Interpret the set inclusion B ⊆ L back into an English statement. This means 'All Bloops are Lazzies'.
paths.final_answer: Yes, all Bloops are definitely Lazzies.

path: Step 1: Use a concrete example to visualize the relationships. Imagine 10 Bloops. Since all Bloops are Razzies, those 10 Bloops are also Razzies.
Step 2: Now, since all Razzies are Lazzies, and we have 10 Razzies (which are also Bloops), these 10 Razzies must also be Lazzies.
Step 3: Therefore, the original 10 Bloops are also Lazzies.
Step 4: Generalize. Since this holds true for any number of Bloops, all Bloops must be Lazzies.
paths.final_answer: Yes, all Bloops are definitely Lazzies.

path: Step 1: Use symbolic logic to represent the statements. Let B(x) mean 'x is a Bloop', R(x) mean 'x is a Razzie', and L(x) mean 'x is a Lazzie'.
Step 2: 'All Bloops are Razzies' can be written as ∀x (B(x) → R(x)).
Step 3: 'All Razzies are Lazzies' can be written as ∀x (R(x) → L(x)).
Step 4: Use the hypothetical syllogism rule: If P → Q and Q → R, then P → R. In this case, if B(x) → R(x) and R(x) → L(x), then B(x) → L(x).
Step 5: Interpret B(x) → L(x) back into an English statement.  ∀x (B(x) → L(x)) means 'For all x, if x is a Bloop, then x is a Lazzie', which is equivalent to 'All Bloops are Lazzies'.
paths.final_answer: Yes, all Bloops are definitely Lazzies.
